turn.0: Hi, I'm your automated assistant. I can answer your questions about Crime and Punishment.
turn.1: What is the end of Crime and Punishment?
turn.2: He thinks that he is self-sufficient and self-contained, but at the end "his boundless self-confidence must disappear in the face of what is greater than himself, and his self-fabricated justification must humble itself before the higher justice of God".
turn.3: Is there anything else interesting about the end of Crime and Punishment?
turn.4: Dostoevsky calls for the regeneration and renewal of "sick" Russian society through the re-discovery of its national identity, its religion, and its roots.
turn.5: What is the most important fact in this article?
turn.6: "Crime and Punishment" is written from a third-person omniscient perspective.
turn.7: Are there any other interesting aspects about this article?
turn.8: It is told primarily from the point of view of Raskolnikov, but does at times switch to the perspective of other characters such as Svidrigaïlov, Razumikhin, Luzhin, Sonya or Dunya.
turn.9: What is the novel's main theme?
turn.10: This narrative technique, which fuses the narrator very closely with the consciousness and point of view of the central characters, was original for its period.
turn.11: What did people say about the novel's technique?
turn.12: Frank notes that Dostoevsky's use of time shifts of memory and manipulation of temporal sequence begins to approach the later experiments of Henry James, Joseph Conrad, Virginia Woolf, and James Joyce.
